text: ਸਕਯਥੁ ਜਨਮੁ ਕਲ੍ਯੁਚਰੈ ਗੁਰੁ ਪਰਸ੍ਯਿਉ ਅਮਰ ਪ੍ਰਗਾਸੁ ॥੮॥

translation.text: So speaks KALL: fruitful is the life of one who meets with Guru Amar Daas, radiant with the Light of God. ||8||

transliteration.text: sakayath janam kalyucharai gur parasyiu amar pragās .8.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:
Poet Kalshar [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Kalshar, who is also known as Kalh and Talh, was the leader of the poets, and taking into consideration the total contribution of hymns by the poets which is 123, Poet Kalshar alone has contributed a considerable 54 hymns.

Poet Kalshar wrote ten hymns in praise of Guru Nanak Dev, ten in praise of Guru Angad Dev, nine in praise of Guru Amar Das, thirteen in praise of Guru Ram Das and twelve in praise of Guru Arjan Dev. Also, he was the son of Chokha, and brother of Poet Gayand.

text: ਬਾਰਿਜੁ ਕਰਿ ਦਾਹਿਣੈ ਸਿਧਿ ਸਨਮੁਖ ਮੁਖੁ ਜੋਵੈ ॥

translation.text: On His right hand is the sign of the lotus; the Siddhis, the supernatural spiritual powers, await His Command.

transliteration.text: bārij kar dāhinai sidh sanamukh mukh jōvai .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:
Poet Kalshar [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Kalshar, who is also known as Kalh and Talh, was the leader of the poets, and taking into consideration the total contribution of hymns by the poets which is 123, Poet Kalshar alone has contributed a considerable 54 hymns.

Poet Kalshar wrote ten hymns in praise of Guru Nanak Dev, ten in praise of Guru Angad Dev, nine in praise of Guru Amar Das, thirteen in praise of Guru Ram Das and twelve in praise of Guru Arjan Dev. Also, he was the son of Chokha, and brother of Poet Gayand.

text: ਰਿਧਿ ਬਸੈ ਬਾਂਵਾਂਗਿ ਜੁ ਤੀਨਿ ਲੋਕਾਂਤਰ ਮੋਹੈ ॥

translation.text: On His left are worldly powers, which fascinate the three worlds.

transliteration.text: ridh basai bānhvānhg j tīn lōkānhtar mōhai .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:
Poet Kalshar [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Kalshar, who is also known as Kalh and Talh, was the leader of the poets, and taking into consideration the total contribution of hymns by the poets which is 123, Poet Kalshar alone has contributed a considerable 54 hymns.

Poet Kalshar wrote ten hymns in praise of Guru Nanak Dev, ten in praise of Guru Angad Dev, nine in praise of Guru Amar Das, thirteen in praise of Guru Ram Das and twelve in praise of Guru Arjan Dev. Also, he was the son of Chokha, and brother of Poet Gayand.

text: ਰਿਦੈ ਬਸੈ ਅਕਹੀਉ ਸੋਇ ਰਸੁ ਤਿਨ ਹੀ ਜਾਤਉ ॥

translation.text: The Inexpressible Lord abides in His Heart; He alone knows this joy.

transliteration.text: ridai basai akahīu sōi ras tin hī jātau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:
Poet Kalshar [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Kalshar, who is also known as Kalh and Talh, was the leader of the poets, and taking into consideration the total contribution of hymns by the poets which is 123, Poet Kalshar alone has contributed a considerable 54 hymns.

Poet Kalshar wrote ten hymns in praise of Guru Nanak Dev, ten in praise of Guru Angad Dev, nine in praise of Guru Amar Das, thirteen in praise of Guru Ram Das and twelve in praise of Guru Arjan Dev. Also, he was the son of Chokha, and brother of Poet Gayand.

text: ਮੁਖਹੁ ਭਗਤਿ ਉਚਰੈ ਅਮਰੁ ਗੁਰੁ ਇਤੁ ਰੰਗਿ ਰਾਤਉ ॥

translation.text: Guru Amar Daas utters the words of devotion, imbued with the Love of the Lord.

transliteration.text: mukhah bhagat ucharai amar gur it rang rātau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:
Poet Kalshar [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Kalshar, who is also known as Kalh and Talh, was the leader of the poets, and taking into consideration the total contribution of hymns by the poets which is 123, Poet Kalshar alone has contributed a considerable 54 hymns.

Poet Kalshar wrote ten hymns in praise of Guru Nanak Dev, ten in praise of Guru Angad Dev, nine in praise of Guru Amar Das, thirteen in praise of Guru Ram Das and twelve in praise of Guru Arjan Dev. Also, he was the son of Chokha, and brother of Poet Gayand.

text: ਮਸਤਕਿ ਨੀਸਾਣੁ ਸਚਉ ਕਰਮੁ ਕਲ੍ਯ ਜੋੜਿ ਕਰ ਧ੍ਯਾਇਅਉ ॥

translation.text: On His forehead is the true insignia of the Lord's Mercy; with his palms pressed together, KALL meditates on Him.

transliteration.text: masatak nīsān sachau karam kaly jōr kar dhyāiau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:

Kalshar, who is also known as Kalh and Talh, was the leader of the poets, and taking into consideration the total contribution of hymns by the poets which is 123, Poet Kalshar alone has contributed a considerable 54 hymns.

Poet Kalshar wrote ten hymns in praise of Guru Nanak Dev, ten in praise of Guru Angad Dev, nine in praise of Guru Amar Das, thirteen in praise of Guru Ram Das and twelve in praise of Guru Arjan Dev. Also, he was the son of Chokha, and brother of Poet Gayand.

text: ਪਰਸਿਅਉ ਗੁਰੂ ਸਤਿਗੁਰ ਤਿਲਕੁ ਸਰਬ ਇਛ ਤਿਨਿ ਪਾਇਅਉ ॥੯॥

translation.text: Whoever meets with the Guru, the certified True Guru, has all his desires fulfilled. ||9||

transliteration.text: parasiau gurū satigur tilak sarab ish tin pāiau .9.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Kalshar
author.description:
Poet Kalshar [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Kalshar, who is also known as Kalh and Talh, was the leader of the poets, and taking into consideration the total contribution of hymns by the poets which is 123, Poet Kalshar alone has contributed a considerable 54 hymns.

Poet Kalshar wrote ten hymns in praise of Guru Nanak Dev, ten in praise of Guru Angad Dev, nine in praise of Guru Amar Das, thirteen in praise of Guru Ram Das and twelve in praise of Guru Arjan Dev. Also, he was the son of Chokha, and brother of Poet Gayand.

text: ਚਰਣ ਤ ਪਰ ਸਕਯਥ ਚਰਣ ਗੁਰ ਅਮਰ ਪਵਲਿ ਰਯ ॥

translation.text: Supremely fruitful are the feet which walk upon the path of Guru Amar Daas.

transliteration.text: charan t par sakayath charan gur amar paval ray .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਹਥ ਤ ਪਰ ਸਕਯਥ ਹਥ ਲਗਹਿ ਗੁਰ ਅਮਰ ਪਯ ॥

translation.text: Supremely fruitful are the hands which touch the feet of Guru Amar Daas.

transliteration.text: hath t par sakayath hath lagah gur amar pay .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਜੀਹ ਤ ਪਰ ਸਕਯਥ ਜੀਹ ਗੁਰ ਅਮਰੁ ਭਣਿਜੈ ॥

translation.text: Supremely fruitful is the tongue which utters the praises of Guru Amar Daas.

transliteration.text: jīh t par sakayath jīh gur amar bhanijai .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਨੈਣ ਤ ਪਰ ਸਕਯਥ ਨਯਣਿ ਗੁਰੁ ਅਮਰੁ ਪਿਖਿਜੈ ॥

translation.text: Supremely fruitful are the eyes which behold Guru Amar Daas.

transliteration.text: nain t par sakayath nayan gur amar pikhijai .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਸ੍ਰਵਣ ਤ ਪਰ ਸਕਯਥ ਸ੍ਰਵਣਿ ਗੁਰੁ ਅਮਰੁ ਸੁਣਿਜੈ ॥

translation.text: Supremely fruitful are the ears which hear the Praises of Guru Amar Daas.

transliteration.text: sravan t par sakayath sravan gur amar sunijai .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਸਕਯਥੁ ਸੁ ਹੀਉ ਜਿਤੁ ਹੀਅ ਬਸੈ ਗੁਰ ਅਮਰਦਾਸੁ ਨਿਜ ਜਗਤ ਪਿਤ ॥

translation.text: Fruitful is the heart in which Guru Amar Daas, the Father of the world, Himself abides.

transliteration.text: sakayath s hīu jit hī basai gur amaradās nij jagat pit .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਸਕਯਥੁ ਸੁ ਸਿਰੁ ਜਾਲਪੁ ਭਣੈ ਜੁ ਸਿਰੁ ਨਿਵੈ ਗੁਰ ਅਮਰ ਨਿਤ ॥੧॥੧੦॥

translation.text: Fruitful is the head, says Jaalap, which bows forever before Guru Amar Daas. ||1||10||

transliteration.text: sakayath s sir jālap bhanai j sir nivai gur amar nit .1.10.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਤਿ ਨਰ ਦੁਖ ਨਹ ਭੁਖ ਤਿ ਨਰ ਨਿਧਨ ਨਹੁ ਕਹੀਅਹਿ ॥

translation.text: They do not suffer pain or hunger, and they cannot be called poor.

transliteration.text: t nar dukh nah bhukh t nar nidhan nah kahīah .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਤਿ ਨਰ ਸੋਕੁ ਨਹੁ ਹੁਐ ਤਿ ਨਰ ਸੇ ਅੰਤੁ ਨ ਲਹੀਅਹਿ ॥

translation.text: They do not grieve, and their limits cannot be found.

transliteration.text: t nar sōk nah huai t nar sē ant n lahīah .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਤਿ ਨਰ ਸੇਵ ਨਹੁ ਕਰਹਿ ਤਿ ਨਰ ਸਯ ਸਹਸ ਸਮਪਹਿ ॥

translation.text: They do not serve anyone else, but they give gifts to hundreds and thousands.

transliteration.text: t nar sēv nah karah t nar say sahas samapah .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਤਿ ਨਰ ਦੁਲੀਚੈ ਬਹਹਿ ਤਿ ਨਰ ਉਥਪਿ ਬਿਥਪਹਿ ॥

translation.text: They sit on beautiful carpets; they establish and disestablish at will.

transliteration.text: t nar dulīchai bahah t nar uthap bithapah .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਸੁਖ ਲਹਹਿ ਤਿ ਨਰ ਸੰਸਾਰ ਮਹਿ ਅਭੈ ਪਟੁ ਰਿਪ ਮਧਿ ਤਿਹ ॥

translation.text: They find peace in this world, and live fearlessly amidst their enemies.

transliteration.text: sukh lahah t nar sansār mah abhai pat rip madh tih .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਸਕਯਥ ਤਿ ਨਰ ਜਾਲਪੁ ਭਣੈ ਗੁਰ ਅਮਰਦਾਸੁ ਸੁਪ੍ਰਸੰਨੁ ਜਿਹ ॥੨॥੧੧॥

translation.text: They are fruitful and prosperous, says Jaalap. Guru Amar Daas is pleased with them. ||2||11||

transliteration.text: sakayath t nar jālap bhanai gur amaradās suprasann jih .2.11.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਤੈ ਪਢਿਅਉ ਇਕੁ ਮਨਿ ਧਰਿਅਉ ਇਕੁ ਕਰਿ ਇਕੁ ਪਛਾਣਿਓ ॥

translation.text: You read about the One Lord, and enshrine Him in Your mind; You realize the One and Only Lord.

transliteration.text: tai padhiau ik man dhariau ik kar ik pashāniō .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਨਯਣਿ ਬਯਣਿ ਮੁਹਿ ਇਕੁ ਇਕੁ ਦੁਹੁ ਠਾਂਇ ਨ ਜਾਣਿਓ ॥

translation.text: With Your eyes and the words You speak, You dwell upon the One Lord; You do not know any other place of rest.

transliteration.text: nayan bayan muh ik ik duh thānhi n jāniō .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਸੁਪਨਿ ਇਕੁ ਪਰਤਖਿ ਇਕੁ ਇਕਸ ਮਹਿ ਲੀਣਉ ॥

translation.text: You know the One Lord while dreaming, and the One Lord while awake. You are absorbed in the One.

transliteration.text: supan ik paratakh ik ikas mah līnau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਤੀਸ ਇਕੁ ਅਰੁ ਪੰਜਿ ਸਿਧੁ ਪੈਤੀਸ ਨ ਖੀਣਉ ॥

translation.text: At the age of seventy-one, You began to march towards the Indestructible Lord.

transliteration.text: tīs ik ar panj sidh paitīs n khīnau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਇਕਹੁ ਜਿ ਲਾਖੁ ਲਖਹੁ ਅਲਖੁ ਹੈ ਇਕੁ ਇਕੁ ਕਰਿ ਵਰਨਿਅਉ ॥

translation.text: The One Lord, who takes hundreds of thousands of forms, cannot be seen. He can only be described as One.

transliteration.text: ikah j lākh lakhah alakh hai ik ik kar varaniau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਗੁਰ ਅਮਰਦਾਸ ਜਾਲਪੁ ਭਣੈ ਤੂ ਇਕੁ ਲੋੜਹਿ ਇਕੁ ਮੰਨਿਅਉ ॥੩॥੧੨॥

translation.text: So speaks Jaalap: O Guru Amar Daas, You long for the One Lord, and believe in the One Lord alone. ||3||12||

transliteration.text: gur amaradās jālap bhanai tū ik lōrah ik manniau .3.12.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਜਿ ਮਤਿ ਗਹੀ ਜੈਦੇਵਿ ਜਿ ਮਤਿ ਨਾਮੈ ਸੰਮਾਣੀ ॥

translation.text: The understanding which Jai Dayv grasped, the understanding which permeated Naam Dayv,

transliteration.text: j mat gahī jaidēv j mat nāmai sanmānī .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਜਿ ਮਤਿ ਤ੍ਰਿਲੋਚਨ ਚਿਤਿ ਭਗਤ ਕੰਬੀਰਹਿ ਜਾਣੀ ॥

translation.text: the understanding which was in the consciousness of Trilochan and known by the devotee Kabeer,

transliteration.text: j mat trilōchan chit bhagat kanbīrah jānī .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਰੁਕਮਾਂਗਦ ਕਰਤੂਤਿ ਰਾਮੁ ਜੰਪਹੁ ਨਿਤ ਭਾਈ ॥

translation.text: by which Rukmaangad constantly meditated on the Lord, O Siblings of Destiny,

transliteration.text: rukamānhgad karatūt rām janpah nit bhāī .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਅੰਮਰੀਕਿ ਪ੍ਰਹਲਾਦਿ ਸਰਣਿ ਗੋਬਿੰਦ ਗਤਿ ਪਾਈ ॥

translation.text: which brought Ambreek and Prahlaad to seek the Sanctuary of the Lord of the Universe, and which brought them to salvation

transliteration.text: anmarīk prahalād saran gōbind gat pāī .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਤੈ ਲੋਭੁ ਕ੍ਰੋਧੁ ਤ੍ਰਿਸਨਾ ਤਜੀ ਸੁ ਮਤਿ ਜਲ੍ਯ ਜਾਣੀ ਜੁਗਤਿ ॥

translation.text: -says JALL that Sublime understanding has brought You to renounce greed, anger and desire, and to know the way.

transliteration.text: tai lōbh krōdh trisanā tajī s mat jaly jānī jugat .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਗੁਰੁ ਅਮਰਦਾਸੁ ਨਿਜ ਭਗਤੁ ਹੈ ਦੇਖਿ ਦਰਸੁ ਪਾਵਉ ਮੁਕਤਿ ॥੪॥੧੩॥

translation.text: Guru Amar Daas is the Lord's own devotee; gazing upon the Blessed Vision of His Darshan, one is liberated. ||4||13||

transliteration.text: gur amaradās nij bhagat hai dēkh daras pāvau mukat .4.13.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਗੁਰੁ ਅਮਰਦਾਸੁ ਪਰਸੀਐ ਪੁਹਮਿ ਪਾਤਿਕ ਬਿਨਾਸਹਿ ॥

translation.text: Meeting with Guru Amar Daas, the earth is purged of its sin.

transliteration.text: gur amaradās parasīai puham pātik bināsah .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਗੁਰੁ ਅਮਰਦਾਸੁ ਪਰਸੀਐ ਸਿਧ ਸਾਧਿਕ ਆਸਾਸਹਿ ॥

translation.text: The Siddhas and seekers long to meet with Guru Amar Daas.

transliteration.text: gur amaradās parasīai sidh sādhik āsāsah .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਗੁਰੁ ਅਮਰਦਾਸੁ ਪਰਸੀਐ ਧਿਆਨੁ ਲਹੀਐ ਪਉ ਮੁਕਿਹਿ ॥

translation.text: Meeting with Guru Amar Daas, the mortal meditates on the Lord, and his journey comes to its end.

transliteration.text: gur amaradās parasīai dhiān lahīai pau mukih .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Jalap
author.description:
Poet Jalap [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Jalap also wrote under the name of Jalh, and wrote 5 hymns, all in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Sikh Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Mathura and Kirat.

text: ਗੁਰੁ ਅਮਰਦਾਸੁ ਪਰਸੀਐ ਅਭਉ ਲਭੈ ਗਉ ਚੁਕਿਹਿ ॥

translation.text: Meeting with Guru Amar Daas, the Fearless Lord is obtained, and the cycle of reincarnation is brought to an end.

transliteration.text: gur amaradās parasīai abhau labhai gau chukih .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood
